Comment: No. The vector is airlines who participate data sharing networks, such as Sabre. The airline pays per flight segment to have their flights listed, which makes the flights easier for consolidators, travel professionals, and other airlines to find. Southwest is the only somewhat major airline I know of that opts out.  Edit: Scratch that. Southwest is a shareholder and has a person on the board of Airlines Reporting Corporation, which is at the center of this investigation. Southwest is also reporting data to the government.

Comment: Southwest is the only airline I know of that does not participate in data sharing networks, so that would be your best bet. Check their privacy policy, though.  Edit: Scratch that. Author: Contunator

Comment: I agree with the parallel comment that the ‚Äútrain experience‚Äù wears off. Sleeping in the seats are a little rough, and the private rooms are expensive and small. If in seats, there are outlets for each row, so if you have a hotspot you can laptop it up. I sometimes travel to other states to participate in bike races, and you can‚Äôt really beat paying ~$50 to travel with your bike 1 or 2 states over. There are really two negatives about Amtrak:  1. In typical American public transportation fashion, some other the cars are not kept clean. One time it smelled like I was sitting in someone else‚Äôs shit for a whole ride. The good thing is you can move to another seat‚Ä¶ as long as there are open seats.  2. The riding experience isn‚Äôt great, but not bad. The seats could be more comfortable, there could be a little more space between people, it could be a better overall experience. With that being said, I travel coach. My view is that trains should be cheaper than airplanes, but if you wanted to get business class or first class those options are there. If you get the first train of the day and you pay ~$50, then there‚Äôs not much you can rightfully complain about.
Author: Rocket_League-Champ

Comment: You‚Äôre allowed two bags up to 50lbs, and a personal item. If you‚Äôre on a train that does checked bags you‚Äôre allowed two more bags up to 50lbs for free, but not all trains have checked bags. Any extra bag is $20, but from my experience from moving to Texas to Michigan by train is when you have to transfer to the train that doesn‚Äôt offer checked baggage, they won‚Äôt charge extra for your carry on bags. Or maybe they didn‚Äôt charge me because they felt bad, because my train was late that I missed my transfer, and they almost lost my bike.
